newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Budapest grains futures rise across the board.
newsitem.headline: Budapest grains futures rise across the board.

text.p: Surging Chicago prices caused limit rises in most grains contracts for the second day running on the Budapest Commodity Exchange (BCE) on Tuesday in minimal turnover, traders said.
"Nobody was prepared to sell as the market expects at least another limit rise," said Istvan Grebats of Termin.
The only actively traded position was the May maize contract which put on 100 forints per tonne to end at 18,550. It accounted for 250 of the day's 330 turnover of contracts.
Grebats added that it was difficult to judge where prices would peak in the hectic Hungarian market.
"There doesn't seem to be a psychological (price) ceiling any longer," he said.
However, current price increases are becoming dangerous for some minor market players, he said.
"There is an increasing danger that some will not be able to finance the current upward movement and will be forced to liquidate positions," Grebats said.
Total grains turnover slumped to 139.2 million forints from Monday's 478.2 million.
